SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Chemotherapeutic options for patients with metastasised colorectal cancer and impaired liver function are limited
Although oxaliplatin and 5-FU are well tolerated as single therapeutic agents, data supporting their use as combination chemotherapy in the setting of severe hepatic dysfunction are insufficient
PATIENTS AND METHODS: Here, we report on 2 patients with colorectal cancer and severe liver dysfunction secondary to hepatic metastases
On admission both patients displayed a bilirubin of > 22 mg/dL and an alkaline phosphatase (AP) of > 350 U/L as signs of extensive hepatic tumor spread
We initiated a 5-FU/oxaliplatin-based combination chemotherapy in both patients
RESULTS: Liver function and clinical performance improved dramatically within the first cycles of therapy in both patients
On radiologic evaluation, we observed 1 partial response and one long-term (10 months) disease stabilization
The toxicity was acceptable in both patients

CONCLUSION: We concluded that oxaliplatin-based combination chemotherapies (eg FOLFOX4) may achieve good tumor response without significant side effects in patients with metastatic colorectal cancer and hepatic dysfunction
